canonical_explanation.text: A linear programming problem (LPP) involves optimizing (maximizing or minimizing) a linear objective function Z=ax+by subject to linear constraints (inequalities). The feasible region is the set of all points satisfying all constraints. By the corner point method, the optimal value of Z occurs at a vertex (corner point) of the feasible region. For bounded regions, both maximum and minimum exist. For unbounded regions, maximum or minimum may or may not exist.
rules: The optimal solution occurs at a corner point of the feasible region
Evaluate Z at each corner point to find maximum/minimum
If feasible region is bounded, both max and min of Z exist
If feasible region is unbounded, check if the half-plane defined by Z=M has common points with feasible region
If no feasible region exists, the LPP has no solution

questions.question_text: In a linear programming problem, the function Z = 3x + 5y that is to be maximized or minimized is called the:
questions.explanation_correct: The linear function Z = ax + by that we want to maximize or minimize is called the objective function in a linear programming problem.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The function to be optimized (maximized or minimized) in an LPP is called the objective function, not a constraint or feasible function.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is NOT a component of a linear programming problem?
questions.explanation_correct: An LPP consists of a linear objective function, linear constraints (inequalities or equations), and non-negativity restrictions. Quadratic inequalities are not part of a linear programming problem.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Linear programming involves only linear expressions. Quadratic inequalities involve squared terms and are not part of an LPP.

questions.question_text: In a linear programming problem, the variables x and y are called decision variables.
questions.explanation_correct: The variables x and y whose values we need to decide are called decision variables in a linear programming problem.
questions.explanation_incorrect: This statement is true. The variables in an LPP are called decision variables because their optimal values need to be determined.

questions.question_text: A factory produces two products A and B. Each unit of A requires 2 hours of machine time and each unit of B requires 3 hours. Total machine time available is 12 hours. Which inequality represents this constraint?
questions.explanation_correct: If x units of A and y units of B are produced, total machine time used is 2x + 3y. Since this cannot exceed the available 12 hours, the constraint is 2x + 3y <= 12.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The total machine time used (2x + 3y) must not exceed the available time (12 hours), giving the inequality 2x + 3y <= 12.

questions.question_text: The set of all feasible solutions of a linear programming problem is called the:
questions.explanation_correct: The common region determined by all the constraints including non-negativity restrictions of an LPP is called the feasible region.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The set of all points satisfying all constraints simultaneously is called the feasible region (or feasible solution region).

questions.question_text: According to the corner point method, the optimal value of the objective function occurs at:

options.text: The centre of the feasible region
Any point inside the feasible region
A vertex (corner point) of the feasible region
The midpoint of any edge of the feasible region

questions.explanation_correct: The Fundamental Theorem of Linear Programming states that the optimal (maximum or minimum) value of the objective function occurs at a corner point (vertex) of the feasible region.
questions.explanation_incorrect: By the corner point method, the optimal value always occurs at a vertex of the feasible region, not at an interior point or midpoint of an edge.

questions.question_text: If the feasible region of an LPP is bounded, then both maximum and minimum values of the objective function exist.
questions.explanation_correct: For a bounded feasible region, the objective function attains both its maximum and minimum values, and these occur at corner points of the feasible region.
questions.explanation_incorrect: This statement is true. A bounded feasible region guarantees the existence of both maximum and minimum values of the objective function at corner points.

questions.question_text: The corner points of the feasible region of an LPP are (0, 0), (4, 0), (2, 3) and (0, 4). The maximum value of Z = 3x + 5y is:
questions.explanation_correct: Evaluate Z at each corner point: Z(0,0) = 0, Z(4,0) = 12, Z(2,3) = 6 + 15 = 21, Z(0,4) = 20. The maximum value is 21 at (2, 3).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Calculate Z = 3x + 5y at each vertex: Z(0,0) = 0, Z(4,0) = 12, Z(2,3) = 21, Z(0,4) = 20. The largest value is 21.

questions.question_text: The corner points of the feasible region are (0, 0), (6, 0), (4, 4) and (0, 6). The minimum value of Z = 2x + 3y is:
questions.explanation_correct: Evaluate Z at each corner point: Z(0,0) = 0, Z(6,0) = 12, Z(4,4) = 8 + 12 = 20, Z(0,6) = 18. The minimum value is 0 at (0, 0).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Calculate Z = 2x + 3y at each vertex: Z(0,0) = 0, Z(6,0) = 12, Z(4,4) = 20, Z(0,6) = 18. The smallest value is 0.

questions.question_text: The corner points of a feasible region are (0, 8), (4, 4) and (8, 0). The value of Z = 5x + 7y at (4, 4) is ___.
A constraint in a linear programming problem must be:

options.text: A linear equation or linear inequality

questions.explanation_correct: Constraints in an LPP can be linear inequalities (<=, >=) or linear equations (=). They must be linear expressions in the decision variables.
questions.explanation_incorrect: In linear programming, constraints are linear expressions and can take the form of equalities or inequalities, but must remain linear.

questions.question_text: A point in the feasible region that satisfies all the constraints is called:
questions.explanation_correct: Any point in the feasible region that satisfies all the constraints including non-negativity restrictions is called a feasible solution.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A point satisfying all constraints is a feasible solution. An optimal solution is the feasible solution that gives the best (max or min) value of the objective function.

questions.question_text: If the feasible region is empty (no common area satisfying all constraints), then the LPP:

options.text: Has a unique solution at the origin

questions.explanation_correct: If there is no feasible region (the constraints are inconsistent), then the LPP has no solution since there is no point satisfying all constraints simultaneously.
questions.explanation_incorrect: When no feasible region exists, no point satisfies all constraints simultaneously, so the LPP has no solution.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is the standard form of the non-negativity restriction in an LPP?
questions.explanation_correct: Non-negativity restrictions require that decision variables are greater than or equal to zero: x >= 0, y >= 0. This restricts the feasible region to the first quadrant.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The standard non-negativity restrictions are x >= 0 and y >= 0, which confine the solution to the first quadrant (including the axes).

questions.question_text: The corner points of a feasible region are (0, 0), (5, 0), (3, 4) and (0, 5). The maximum value of Z = 4x + 3y is ___.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Evaluate Z = 4x + 3y at all vertices: Z(0,0) = 0, Z(5,0) = 20, Z(3,4) = 24, Z(0,5) = 15. The maximum is 24.

questions.question_text: A feasible region that can be enclosed within a circle is called:
questions.explanation_correct: A feasible region is bounded if it can be enclosed within a circle, meaning it does not extend to infinity in any direction.
questions.explanation_incorrect: If a feasible region can be enclosed in a circle (i.e., it is finite in extent), it is called a bounded feasible region.

questions.question_text: A dietician mixes two foods F1 and F2. F1 costs Rs 4 per unit and F2 costs Rs 6 per unit. The objective function to minimize cost is:

options.text: Z = 4x + 6y, where x = units of F1, y = units of F2
Z = 6x + 4y, where x = units of F1, y = units of F2
Z = 4x - 6y, where x = units of F1, y = units of F2

questions.explanation_correct: If x units of F1 and y units of F2 are used, the total cost is Z = 4x + 6y. This is the objective function to be minimized.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The cost of x units of F1 at Rs 4 each is 4x, and y units of F2 at Rs 6 each is 6y. Total cost Z = 4x + 6y.

questions.question_text: For an unbounded feasible region, the maximum value of the objective function always exists.
questions.explanation_correct: For an unbounded feasible region, the maximum (or minimum) value of the objective function may or may not exist. We must check whether the open half-plane determined by Z = M has common points with the feasible region.
questions.explanation_incorrect: This is false. In an unbounded region, the objective function may increase without bound, so a maximum may not exist.

questions.question_text: In formulating an LPP, if a manufacturer can produce at most 10 units of product A, the constraint is:
questions.explanation_correct: 'At most 10 units' means the production x can be any value up to and including 10, so the constraint is x <= 10.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The phrase 'at most 10' translates to 'less than or equal to 10', giving the constraint x <= 10.

questions.question_text: In formulating an LPP, if a customer requires at least 20 units of a product, the constraint is:
questions.explanation_correct: 'At least 20 units' means the quantity must be 20 or more, so the constraint is x >= 20.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The phrase 'at least 20' translates to 'greater than or equal to 20', giving the constraint x >= 20.

questions.question_text: Maximize Z = 5x + 3y subject to: x + y <= 8, 2x + y <= 12, x >= 0, y >= 0. The maximum value of Z is:
questions.explanation_incorrect: Evaluate Z = 5x+3y at corners (0,0), (6,0), (4,4), (0,8): values are 0, 30, 32, 24. The maximum is 32 at (4,4).

questions.question_text: Minimize Z = 3x + 5y subject to: x + y >= 4, x + 3y >= 6, x >= 0, y >= 0. The minimum value of Z is:
questions.explanation_correct: Corner points of the unbounded feasible region: On y-axis (x=0): y>=4 and 3y>=6 so y>=4, giving (0,4). Intersection of x+y=4 and x+3y=6: subtract to get 2y=2, y=1, x=3, giving (3,1). On x-axis (y=0): x>=4 and x>=6, so (6,0). Z(0,4)=20, Z(3,1)=9+5=14, Z(6,0)=18. The smallest is 14 at (3,1). Since no feasible point satisfies 3x+5y<14, the minimum is 14.

questions.question_text: Maximize Z = 4x + y subject to: x + y <= 50, 3x + y <= 90, x >= 0, y >= 0. The maximum value of Z is:
questions.explanation_correct: Corner points: (0,0), (30,0) [from 3x+y=90 on x-axis], intersection of x+y=50 and 3x+y=90: subtract to get 2x=40, x=20, y=30, giving (20,30), and (0,50). Z(0,0)=0, Z(30,0)=120, Z(20,30)=80+30=110, Z(0,50)=50. Maximum is 120 at (30,0).

questions.question_text: A manufacturer produces two types of toys A and B. Toy A requires 5 min for cutting and 10 min for assembling. Toy B requires 8 min for cutting and 8 min for assembling. Total cutting time = 3 hrs 20 min, total assembling time = 4 hrs. Profit is Rs 50 per toy A and Rs 60 per toy B. The correct constraints (in minutes) are:
questions.explanation_correct: Cutting: 5x + 8y <= 200 (3h 20min = 200 min). Assembling: 10x + 8y <= 240 (4h = 240 min). With x >= 0, y >= 0.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Convert to minutes: 3h 20min = 200 min, 4h = 240 min. Cutting constraint: 5x + 8y <= 200. Assembling constraint: 10x + 8y <= 240.

questions.question_text: A manufacturer produces items P and Q. Item P needs 2 hrs on Machine I and 3 hrs on Machine II. Item Q needs 4 hrs on Machine I and 2 hrs on Machine II. Machine I available for 16 hrs and Machine II for 12 hrs daily. Profit: P = Rs 40, Q = Rs 50. The corner points of the feasible region are (0,0), (0,4), (2,3) and (4,0). The maximum profit is:
Minimize Z = 3x + 4y subject to: x + 2y >= 8, 3x + 2y >= 12, x >= 0, y >= 0. The minimum value of Z is:
questions.explanation_correct: Corner points: On y-axis (x=0): y>=6 (from both constraints), giving (0,6). Intersection of x+2y=8 and 3x+2y=12: subtract to get 2x=4, x=2, y=3, giving (2,3). On x-axis (y=0): x>=8, giving (8,0). Z(0,6)=24, Z(2,3)=6+12=18, Z(8,0)=24. Since no feasible point gives Z<18 (verified by checking that the half-plane 3x+4y<18 has no common point with the feasible region), the minimum is 18 at (2,3).

questions.question_text: A diet problem requires at least 10 units of vitamin A and 12 units of vitamin B daily. Food F1 provides 2 units of A and 1 unit of B per kg. Food F2 provides 1 unit of A and 4 units of B per kg. F1 costs Rs 50/kg and F2 costs Rs 70/kg. The constraints for this LPP are:
questions.explanation_correct: Vitamin A: 2x + y >= 10. Vitamin B: x + 4y >= 12. 'At least' translates to >=. Non-negativity: x >= 0, y >= 0.
questions.explanation_incorrect: F1 gives 2 units of A and 1 of B per kg. F2 gives 1 of A and 4 of B per kg. Minimum requirements use >=: 2x + y >= 10 and x + 4y >= 12.

questions.question_text: Maximize Z = 3x + 2y subject to: x + 2y <= 10, 3x + y <= 15, x >= 0, y >= 0. The maximum value of Z is:
questions.explanation_correct: Corner points: (0,0), (5,0), intersection of x+2y=10 and 3x+y=15: multiply first by 3 to get 3x+6y=30, subtract second: 5y=15, y=3, x=4, giving (4,3), and (0,5). Z(0,0)=0, Z(5,0)=15, Z(4,3)=12+6=18, Z(0,5)=10. Maximum is 18 at (4,3).

questions.question_text: The feasible region is bounded with corner points (0, 0), (10, 0), (6, 8) and (0, 12). If the maximum of Z = px + qy (where p, q > 0) occurs at both (10, 0) and (6, 8), then:
questions.explanation_correct: If Z has the same value at (10,0) and (6,8): 10p + 0 = 6p + 8q, so 4p = 8q, giving p = 2q.
questions.explanation_incorrect: For maximum at both points: Z(10,0) = Z(6,8) => 10p = 6p + 8q => 4p = 8q => p = 2q.

questions.question_text: A company makes two products X and Y. Each unit of X needs 1 hour on Machine A and 2 hours on Machine B. Each unit of Y needs 3 hours on Machine A and 1 hour on Machine B. Machine A is available 9 hours and Machine B is available 8 hours. Profit is Rs 40 per X and Rs 50 per Y. The maximum profit is:
questions.explanation_correct: Constraints: x + 3y <= 9, 2x + y <= 8, x >= 0, y >= 0. Corner points: (0,0), (4,0) [from 2x+y=8 on x-axis], intersection of x+3y=9 and 2x+y=8: multiply second by 3: 6x+3y=24, subtract first: 5x=15, x=3, y=2, giving (3,2), and (0,3) [from x+3y=9 on y-axis]. Z = 40x+50y: Z(0,0)=0, Z(4,0)=160, Z(3,2)=120+100=220, Z(0,3)=150. Maximum is Rs 220 at (3,2).

questions.question_text: Minimize Z = 2x + y subject to: x + y >= 6, 2x + y >= 8, x >= 0, y >= 0. The minimum value of Z is:
questions.explanation_correct: Corners: On y-axis (x=0): y>=6 and y>=8, so (0,8). Intersection of x+y=6 and 2x+y=8: subtract to get x=2, y=4, giving (2,4). On x-axis (y=0): x>=6 and 2x>=8 so x>=6, giving (6,0). Z(0,8)=8, Z(2,4)=4+4=8, Z(6,0)=12. The smallest is 8. Since 2x+y>=8 is itself a constraint, Z=2x+y cannot be less than 8 in the feasible region. Minimum is 8.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Corners: (0,8), (2,4), (6,0). Z = 2x+y: 8, 8, 12. Minimum is 8, confirmed since 2x+y >= 8 is a constraint.

questions.question_text: A factory makes two models A and B. Model A requires 9 hours of labour and 1 hour of polishing. Model B requires 12 hours of labour and 3 hours of polishing. Maximum labour = 180 hours and polishing = 30 hours. Profit: Rs 8000 per A and Rs 12000 per B. The constraints are:
questions.explanation_correct: Labour: 9x + 12y <= 180. Polishing: x + 3y <= 30. Non-negativity: x >= 0, y >= 0.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Model A needs 9 labour + 1 polishing hours, Model B needs 12 labour + 3 polishing hours. Constraints: 9x + 12y <= 180 and x + 3y <= 30.

questions.question_text: The corner points of the feasible region are A(0, 4), B(2, 2) and C(4, 0). If Z = ax + by (a, b > 0) has its maximum value at both A and B, then:
questions.explanation_correct: If Z is the same at A(0,4) and B(2,2): 0 + 4b = 2a + 2b, so 2b = 2a, giving a = b.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Z(A) = Z(B) gives 4b = 2a + 2b, so 2b = 2a, hence a = b.

questions.question_text: The corner points of a bounded feasible region are (0, 10), (5, 5), (10, 0) and (0, 0). The minimum value of Z = 6x + 10y (excluding origin) among non-origin vertices is ___.
questions.explanation_correct: Z at non-origin corners: Z(0,10) = 0+100 = 100, Z(5,5) = 30+50 = 80, Z(10,0) = 60+0 = 60. The minimum among these is 60 at (10,0).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Z = 6x + 10y: Z(0,10) = 100, Z(5,5) = 80, Z(10,0) = 60. The smallest non-origin value is 60.

questions.question_text: Maximize Z = x + y subject to: x + y <= 1, y - x <= 0, x >= 0, y >= 0. The maximum value of Z is:
questions.explanation_correct: From y-x<=0: y<=x. Corners: (0,0), (1,0) [x+y=1 on x-axis with y=0<=x=1], (1/2,1/2) [intersection of x+y=1 and y=x]. Z(0,0)=0, Z(1,0)=1, Z(1/2,1/2)=1. Maximum Z = 1, attained at both (1,0) and (1/2,1/2).
questions.explanation_incorrect: The corners are (0,0), (1,0), (1/2,1/2). Z = x+y: 0, 1, 1. Maximum is 1, attained at two vertices.

questions.question_text: A dietician wants to mix two foods I and II. Food I has 2 units of vitamin A, 1 unit of vitamin B, and 1 unit of vitamin C per kg. Food II has 1 unit of A, 1 unit of B, and 3 units of C per kg. Minimum requirements: 8 units A, 5 units B, 7 units C. Food I costs Rs 5/kg, Food II costs Rs 8/kg. Which formulation is correct?

options.text: Minimize Z = 5x+8y subject to 2x+y>=8, x+y>=5, x+3y>=7, x>=0, y>=0
Maximize Z = 5x+8y subject to 2x+y<=8, x+y<=5, x+3y<=7, x>=0, y>=0
Minimize Z = 5x+8y subject to 2x+y<=8, x+y<=5, x+3y<=7, x>=0, y>=0
Minimize Z = 8x+5y subject to 2x+y>=8, x+y>=5, x+3y>=7, x>=0, y>=0

questions.explanation_correct: We minimize cost Z = 5x + 8y. 'At least' requirements give >= constraints: 2x+y>=8 (vit A), x+y>=5 (vit B), x+3y>=7 (vit C), with x,y>=0.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Cost = 5x+8y to minimize. Minimum nutrient requirements mean >= inequalities: 2x+y>=8, x+y>=5, x+3y>=7.

questions.question_text: Maximize Z = 5x + 10y subject to: x + 2y <= 120, x + y <= 80, x >= 0, y >= 0. The maximum value of Z is:
Minimize Z = 13x - 15y subject to: x + y <= 7, 2x - 3y + 6 >= 0, x >= 0, y >= 0. The corner points are (0, 0), (7, 0), (3, 4), (0, 2). The minimum value of Z is:
Maximize Z = 2x + 5y subject to: 2x + 4y <= 8, 3x + y <= 6, x + y <= 4, x >= 0, y >= 0. The maximum value of Z is:

Two tailors A and B earn Rs 150 and Rs 200 per day respectively. A can stitch 6 shirts and 4 pants per day. B can stitch 10 shirts and 4 pants per day. To produce at least 60 shirts and 32 pants at minimum labour cost, the minimum cost is:
questions.explanation_correct: Let A work x days, B work y days. Constraints: 6x+10y>=60 (shirts), 4x+4y>=32 (pants), x,y>=0. Simplify: 3x+5y>=30, x+y>=8. Minimize Z=150x+200y. Corners: On x-axis: x>=10 and x>=8, so (10,0). Intersection of 3x+5y=30 and x+y=8: from second x=8-y, sub: 3(8-y)+5y=30, 24+2y=30, y=3, x=5, giving (5,3). On y-axis: 5y>=30 so y>=6, and y>=8, so (0,8). Z(10,0)=1500, Z(5,3)=750+600=1350, Z(0,8)=1600. Minimum is 1350 at (5,3).

questions.question_text: A company manufactures souvenirs of two types A and B. Type A requires 5 min cutting and 10 min assembling. Type B requires 8 min cutting and 8 min assembling. Cutting time available: 3 hrs 20 min, assembling time: 4 hrs. Profit: Rs 50 per A, Rs 60 per B. The maximum profit is:
The corner points of the feasible region determined by x + y <= 10, 2x + 3y <= 24, x >= 0, y >= 0 are (0,0), (10,0), (6,4) and (0,8). The point at which Z = 7x + 4y is maximized is:
questions.explanation_incorrect: Z = 7x+4y at corners: 0, 70, 58, 32. Maximum Z = 70 at (10,0).

questions.question_text: Maximize Z = x + 2y subject to: x + 2y >= 100, 2x - y <= 0, 2x + y <= 200, x >= 0, y >= 0. The maximum value of Z is:
questions.explanation_correct: From 2x-y<=0: y>=2x. From 2x+y<=200 and y>=2x: on y-axis (x=0), y<=200. Corners of the feasible region: intersection of y=2x and x+2y=100: x+4x=100, x=20, y=40, giving (20,40). Intersection of y=2x and 2x+y=200: 4x=200, x=50, y=100, giving (50,100). On y-axis: x=0, y>=2(0)=0, x+2y>=100 gives y>=50, 2x+y<=200 gives y<=200. So (0,200) and (0,50). Z=x+2y: Z(20,40)=100, Z(50,100)=250, Z(0,200)=400, Z(0,50)=100. Maximum is 400 at (0,200).

questions.question_text: A merchant sells desktops and laptops. He can sell at most 20 computers. A desktop costs Rs 25000 and a laptop costs Rs 50000. His budget is Rs 750000. Profit: Rs 4500 per desktop and Rs 5000 per laptop. The maximum profit is:
questions.explanation_correct: Let x = desktops, y = laptops. Constraints: x+y<=20, 25000x+50000y<=750000 i.e. x+2y<=30, x,y>=0. Maximize Z = 4500x+5000y. Corners: (0,0), (20,0) [check: 20+0=20<=30, yes], intersection of x+y=20 and x+2y=30: subtract to get y=10, x=10, giving (10,10), and (0,15) [from x+2y=30 on y-axis]. Z(0,0)=0, Z(20,0)=90000, Z(10,10)=45000+50000=95000, Z(0,15)=75000. Maximum is Rs 95000 at (10,10).

questions.question_text: Minimize Z = 200x + 500y subject to: x + 2y >= 10, 3x + 4y <= 24, x >= 0, y >= 0. The minimum value of Z is:
questions.explanation_correct: Feasible corners: On y-axis, x+2y>=10 gives y>=5 and 4y<=24 gives y<=6, so (0,5) and (0,6). Intersection of x+2y=10 and 3x+4y=24: x=10-2y, sub: 30-6y+4y=24, y=3, x=4, giving (4,3). Note (8,0) from 3x+4y=24 fails x+2y>=10. Corners: (0,5), (4,3), (0,6). Z(0,5)=2500, Z(4,3)=800+1500=2300, Z(0,6)=3000. Minimum is 2300 at (4,3).

questions.question_text: A transport company has two godowns A and B with stocks of 30 and 70 units respectively. They supply to dealers C and D who need 40 and 60 units respectively. The cost of transportation per unit (in Rs) from A to C, A to D, B to C, B to D is 7, 3, 5, 4 respectively. If x units are sent from A to C, then the total transportation cost Z is:
questions.explanation_correct: A sends x to C, so A sends (30-x) to D. C needs 40 total, so B sends (40-x) to C. D needs 60 total, so B sends 60-(30-x) = (30+x) to D. Cost Z = 7x + 3(30-x) + 5(40-x) + 4(30+x) = 7x + 90 - 3x + 200 - 5x + 120 + 4x = 3x + 410. Constraints: 0 <= x <= 30.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A sends x to C, (30-x) to D. B sends (40-x) to C, (30+x) to D. Z = 7x + 3(30-x) + 5(40-x) + 4(30+x) = 3x + 410.

questions.question_text: If the objective function Z = px + qy has the same maximum value at two adjacent corner points of a bounded feasible region, then every point on the line segment joining these two points also gives the same maximum value.
questions.explanation_correct: If Z has the same value at two adjacent vertices of a bounded feasible region, then by linearity of Z, every point on the segment joining them gives the same Z value. This results in infinitely many optimal solutions.
questions.explanation_incorrect: This is true. Since Z is linear and equals the same value at both endpoints, it must equal that value at every convex combination of those points.

questions.question_text: Maximize Z = 11x + 7y subject to the constraints whose feasible region has corner points (0, 2), (3, 0), (6, 0), (6, 8) and (0, 5). The maximum value of Z is:
questions.explanation_incorrect: Z = 11x+7y at all vertices: 14, 33, 66, 122, 35. The maximum is 122 at (6,8).

questions.question_text: A farmer has two types of fertilizers F1 and F2. F1 contains 10% nitrogen and 6% phosphoric acid. F2 contains 5% nitrogen and 10% phosphoric acid. He needs at least 14 kg of nitrogen and 14 kg of phosphoric acid. If F1 costs Rs 7/kg and F2 costs Rs 5/kg, and x kg of F1 and y kg of F2 are used, the minimum cost is:
questions.explanation_correct: Constraints: 0.1x + 0.05y >= 14 i.e. 2x+y >= 280, and 0.06x + 0.1y >= 14 i.e. 3x+5y >= 700. Minimize Z = 7x+5y, x,y >= 0. Corner points: On x-axis: x >= 700/3 (from 3x >= 700), so (700/3, 0). On y-axis: y >= 280 (from y >= 280), so (0, 280). Intersection of 2x+y=280 and 3x+5y=700: y=280-2x, sub: 3x+1400-10x=700, x=100, y=80, giving (100, 80). Z(700/3, 0) = 4900/3 = 1633.3, Z(100,80) = 700+400 = 1100, Z(0,280) = 1400. Since no feasible point gives Z < 1100, the minimum is Rs 1100 at (100, 80).

questions.question_text: Consider the LPP: Maximize Z = 3x + 9y subject to x + 3y <= 60, x + y >= 10, x <= y, x >= 0, y >= 0. The corner points of the feasible region are (0, 10), (5, 5), (15, 15) and (0, 20). The maximum value of Z is:
